howto.title: How to Play
howto.content:
• Visit each planet and help local students to defeat Captain Corruptus by answering their questions.
  • Make sure you don't lose a planet by giving students bad advice.
  • Your progress is saved automatically, so you can exit the game and resume play at a later time.
  • Visit planets again to improve your results.

download.title: Discussion Guide
download.content:
This game comes with a Discussion Guide that was created for instructors to help them facilitate and adapt the game to their needs.

The PDF also contains discussion questions that can be used to help evaluate student performance across the 3 planets.

Download Discussion Guide (PDF)

intro.text: The Akadema Galaxy was once an oasis for the brightest students in the universe. That is, until Captain Corruptus began his wicked crusade to corrupt the minds of the galaxy.

Captain Corruptus is using his sinister invention, the Misinformation Ray to weaken students' originality, ethics, and independence. He wants students to quit school and join his League of the Unearned, a force that could soon destroy Akadema!
You must help Akadema's students to make the right choices! The integrity of the Galaxy is in your hands.

planets.name: Colaborea
planets.info:
Welcome to planet Colaborea, home to some of the most effective team-workers in the galaxy. Captain Corruptus is using a Misinformation Ray to make the students of Colaborea work together unethically. Don't let the students join Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned.

You must help them! The integrity of the planet is in your hands.

victory.message: You have succeeded in helping the students of Colaborea to to avoid unethically collaborating. The planet and its effective teams are now safe from Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned!

defeat.message: You have lost Colaborea to Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned. Try playing this planet again to beat Captain Corruptus.

planets.name: The Archive of Bosh
planets.info:
Welcome to Bosh - the archive planet, home to some of the best researchers in the galaxy. Captain Corruptus is using a Misinformation Ray to make the students of Bosh fail to cite their sources. Don't let the students join Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned.

You must help them! The integrity of the planet is in your hands.

victory.message: You have succeeded in helping the students of Bosh to avoid misusing their research and sources. The planet and its vast archives are now safe from Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned!

defeat.message: You have lost The Archive of Bosh to Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned. Try playing this planet again to beat Captain Corruptus.

planets.name: Cheel
planets.info:
Welcome planet Cheel, a tranquil planet of students and academies . Captain Corruptus is using a Misinformation Ray to make the students of Cheel have difficulty managing their stress levels. Don't let the students join Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned.

You must help them! The integrity of the planet is in your hands.

victory.message: You have succeeded in helping the students of Cheel to manage their stress and workloads more effectively. The planet and its students are now safe from Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned!

defeat.message: You have lost Cheel to Captain Corruptus's League of the Unearned. Try playing this planet again to beat Captain Corruptus.

conversation.question: In my Galactic History course we have to post to a discussion board every week. Everybody is reading the same articles, so I'm not going to worry about my post being original.
hints: Through the eyes of one alien, the stars are aligned. To another they're criss-crossed. To the other, divine.

options.label: Right!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Your instructor will be looking for your unique perspective, conveyed in your unique words. Make it easier on yourself by not reading your classmates' posts until after you've written and posted yours.

options.label: Wrong!
options.feedback: Correct! Your instructor will be looking for your unique perspective, conveyed in your unique words. Make it easier on yourself by not reading your classmates' posts until after you've written and posted yours.

conversation.question: That doesn't make sense. How many different ways can you say "In 2430 the Mantorians discovered X"?!
hints: Words draw a picture, each image unique. Find your perspective and share what you think.

options.label: 5 different ways
options.feedback: Sorry, that's incorrect. Every person has a unique way of writing (aka "voice"). Also, your purpose for writing is different from the original author's. Combine your unique voice with your purpose, and you'll generate original content.

options.label: 5000+ different ways
options.feedback: Correct! Every person has a unique way of writing (aka "voice"). Also, your purpose for writing is different from the original author's. Combine your unique voice with your purpose, and you'll generate original content.

conversation.question: Okay, so I need to write in my own words. This week's DB is about the great migration of the Florkle species. Everything I write will be from our reading, so do I really need to cite it?
hints: Starships warp through space, trails left behind. Follow them closely and the starships you'll find.

options.label: Yep, you should cite it
options.feedback: Correct! Use citations in all assignments, and don't forget quotation marks if you're using their words!

options.label: Nah, you're good
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Use citations in all assignments, and don't forget quotation marks if you're using their words!

conversation.question: Let's say I grab some text from the article, swap some of the words with synonyms, and add in-text citations. Am I good then?
hints: Shakespeare said, "To thine own self be true." Would changing "own self" to "yourself" be Shakespeare or you?

options.label: Yeah, that sounds fine
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Swapping words isn't paraphrasing. You also need to change the structure and include quotation marks around sections of text you keep.

options.label: Nope
options.feedback: Correct! Swapping words isn't paraphrasing. You also need to change the structure and include quotation marks around sections of text you keep.

conversation.question: Honestly, for busywork like this, I don't even understand why it's that important to be original in the first place.
hints: What looks like time wasted may in fact be prime time, to practise your craft and to master your mind.

options.label: Yeah, it's just for participation marks
options.feedback: Incorrect. Small assignments build into the larger course goals and help you master the course content.

options.label: It is important to present your ideas clearly and honestly, even for small assignments
options.feedback: Correct! Small assignments build into the larger course goals and help you master the course content.

conversation.question: Got it, but it seems like discussion boards are pretty casual, so I'll just paraphrase stuff from the course or Zoogle and include a citation.
hints: A parrot can parrot a word or a phrase, a human can think in so many ways.

options.label: Guaranteed "A"!
options.feedback: That might be okay, but usually professors want more than just a repeat of what you read. They want to see your ideas.

options.label: Maybe
options.feedback: That might be okay, but usually professors want more than just a repeat of what you read. They want to see your ideas.

boss.question: What are the characteristics of a strong discussion board post?

options.label: Paraphrases course content, has citations, and includes your ideas.
options.feedback: Correct! Paraphrases course content, has citations, and includes your ideas.

options.label: Quotes course content, has citations, and includes your ideas.
options.feedback: Wrong! Quotes course content, has citations, and includes your ideas.

conversation.question: Did anyone else feel that Solar Flare yesterday? I could have sworn I saw tomorrow's test questions posted on the course portal.

I felt it!!! I was on the portal and it flickered for a whole minute, then I saw all the "restricted" files. Your guy over here (that's me) managed to download a copy before it was hidden again. Send me 50 BlargBucks and I'll send you a copy.
I dunno about that. It doesn't sound super legal. What if we get in trouble?

options.label: Yeah that is def illegal. I say we avoid it.
options.feedback: This exam would be considered stolen no matter who posted it, even the prof.

options.label: The prof was the one who posted them, plus I have so many tests coming up. Count me in!
options.feedback: That is a really bad idea. You've basically stolen an exam!

conversation.question: OK, OK, fine. I won't make money - but I'll blame you when I can't afford BeatBot3000 tickets!  If 10 people send me 5 BlargBucks each, howzabout I post the document here for everyone?
Orrrr... how about you post example questions here, we divide and conquer, and all contribute answers together? That doesn't seem to be crossing a line, right?
I could really use a break - I'm so overwhelmed and everything is due at once!

options.label: Last year, I had two tests and a paper due in the same week, so I asked my prof if I could hand the paper in later. It really helped. The prof also told me about a student support resource I had never heard of!
options.feedback: If you are overloaded with work, there are supports available to you - you just need to ask for them.

options.label: You can get everything done! You just need to cut some corners. Like accessing these questions!
options.feedback: There are many other ways to manage a high workload - such as asking for support from instructors or using resources provided by your institution - none of which will get you in trouble with the school or the law.

conversation.question: Well, how about we agree to have this chat open during the exam in case any of us needs help?
Waitaminute - are you even in this class?! We are definitely not supposed to communicate or have an open chat during a test. Are you trying to get us all in trouble?
I am just trying to help people...and make a little money at the same time. It's your loss if you pass up this opportunity to get ahead. Bye, losers. [Disconnects]
Who *was* that?!  I think I need to email Professor Blargon about this.

options.label: Definitely! Professor Blargon should know about this.
options.feedback: You should absolutely make your professor aware of any scams or attempted unethical behaviour.

options.label: You're probably right - we could all get in trouble just knowing about it, but I'm not a snitch! What if Alder finds out??
options.feedback: It is always better to keep the prof informed, especially because you may not be the only group Alder tried to influence.

boss.question: Is the use of social media chat groups or apps the best way to find information and help for courses and assignments?

options.label: Yes
options.feedback: Sorry! That's incorrect!

options.label: No
options.feedback: That is correct!

conversation.question: My roommate is working extra night shifts so we can have a wall-sized HoloScreen. All of my classes are in the mornings, so sometimes I log in as him to go to his lectures! I'm still trying to think of what he could do that would help me out in my hardest class...
hints: A back that needs scratching will always be itchy, and ill-gotten knowledge will always be glitchy.

options.label: Great system! We only have so many tentacles!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Even if you're in the same program as a friend, it doesn't mean you can attend classes for them.

options.label: You're both in Rocket Propulsion Engineering, but I don't think you should do that...
options.feedback: Correct! Even if you're in the same program as a friend, it doesn't mean you can attend classes for them.

conversation.question: It's not like I'm in the room - it's on the other side of a screen! No one knows, and his name appears in the attendance list, so he doesn't lose any marks for something that's not his fault anyway... .
hints: What knowledge is true for the fool who bends rules?

options.label: Blargh! You're not only going instead of him, but you're also claiming to be him? Even if attendance didn't count, it's still pretty bad.
options.feedback: Correct! Impersonation is impersonation, even if no marks are involved.

options.label: You're helping each other out! I won't tell, and you invite me over when you get that HoloScreen!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Impersonation is impersonation, even if no marks are involved.

conversation.question: Hmm, now that you mention it, the TA did put me in a breakout room for a discussion group... but what about if it's an emergency, like my roommate comes down with SpaceFever? Couldn't I pretend to be him, just when he is sick?
hints: One favour magnified reveals fraud to identify.

options.label: It sounds like everyone has the best intentions, so how could it be a problem? You're just helping!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Tell your roommate to contact his instructor or academic advisor to help him manage unexpected events, such as illness or absences.

options.label: It sounds like you're playing with radioactive sludge, here. There are other ways to help!
options.feedback: Correct! Tell your roommate to contact his instructor or academic advisor to help him manage unexpected events, such as illness or absences.

conversation.question: Anybody could be anybody in there if they don't turn their camera on. If the prof never checks, why does it matter?
hints: Star fragments aplenty in black holes that look empty.

options.label: They want to be able to trust everyone to be who they say they are! If they can't trust us, they'll ask for tentacle scans next year!
options.feedback: Correct! Remote teaching and learning requires trust to succeed. Even if a class is not in person, only enrolled students should attend.

options.label: You've got a good point - it's such a small thing, so you're fine.
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Remote teaching and learning requires trust to succeed. Even if a class is not in person, only enrolled students should attend.

conversation.question: Well, I've already paid my share for the HoloScreen, so my roommate has to do something big to make it up to me. I am thinking of getting them to take a quiz for me next week. It's only 5% and I know he'll ace it.
hints: Mistakes will repeat with a contract to cheat.

options.label: Seems fair to me - he really owes you one!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Engaging in misrepresentation or impersonation, no matter the value of an assignment, can lead to serious penalties, such as suspension or expulsion.

options.label: This is what I was worried about - you did something that seemed minor, and now it's going to get really major. That is definitely impersonation!
options.feedback: Correct! Engaging in misrepresentation or impersonation, no matter the value of an assignment, can lead to serious penalties, such as suspension or expulsion.

conversation.question: Ok, ok, fine - what if I am the one writing it, but I get their help to answer some questions?  Like, they are just... helping me.
hints: If improperly installed, all functions will stall.

options.label: Teamwork makes the HoloScreen work!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Friends don't help friends cheat.

options.label: It's not "helping" here any more - neither of you is going to learn enough to do the work yourself. Your roommate needs to choose - class or work - so you don't both get in major, major trouble.
options.feedback: Correct! Friends don't help friends cheat.

options.label: Honestly, I don't care if you just invite me over for HoloScreen time!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. Friends don't help friends cheat.

conversation.question: You've got me thinking - I don't want to scan my tentacle for every class next year. How do I get my roommate to stop expecting this now? He really relies on me!
hints: Guidance systems are operating at 100%.

options.label: It's not just about him any more, since you're involved and could get in big trouble, too - help him make an appointment to talk to an advisor about his schedule.
options.feedback: Correct! It's never too late to do the right thing. A better way to help a friend is to support them in accessing your institution's resources for students.

options.label: If it's been working, don't change a thing. Worry about consequences for next year... next year!
options.feedback: Sorry, that's wrong. It's never too late to do the right thing. A better way to help a friend is to support them in accessing your institution's resources for students.

boss.question: If an assignment does not specify that group work is allowed, is a student is expected to complete all components, steps, or requirements individually?

options.label: Yes
options.feedback: That is correct!

options.label: No
options.feedback: Sorry! That is wrong!

conversation.question: Dude, I'm neurodiverse! I got accommodations in HS. If I don't get them here I'll just take the extra time!
hints: Time is a construct, slippery and wild; tame it quite simply with documents you filed.

options.label: Go for it.
options.feedback: Wong. You have a responsibility to connect with the academic accommodations office to request any accommodations.

options.label: I wouldn't!
options.feedback: Correct. You have a responsibility to connect with the academic accommodations office to request any accommodations.

conversation.question: There's not enough time to ask for more time - the test is in two days! I'll just say my Internet went down. Heh heh.
hints: Every click leaves a trace, every connection a trail. Game the system with lies and the gamer will fail.

options.label: Works every time.
options.feedback: Wrong. The learning management system where you complete your tests can identify these kinds of tricks. Instead, try to get emergency accommodations.

options.label: Don't you think they know that trick?
options.feedback: Correct. The learning management system where you complete your tests can identify these kinds of tricks. Instead, try to get emergency accommodations.

conversation.question: The Accommodations website says to read the policy, but it's like reading a contract full of "subsection" this and "heretofore" that. Makes my brain hurt. Maybe I should hire a lawyer.
hints: No alien is an island, no circle a square. Talk to your advisor, they've wisdom to share.

options.label: Seems like money well spent!
options.feedback: Wrong. Case managers and advisors are there to support you and can help you understand complex policies.

options.label: An accommodations case manager can help!
options.feedback: Correct. Case managers and advisors are there to support you and can help you understand complex policies.

conversation.question: The website says my documentation is too old, but I can't afford to get a new assessment; those things are expensive and an alien has got to eat!
hints: Don't be embarrassed, ashamed or afraid. Ask for some help while your pizza is made.

options.label: Order pizza.
options.feedback: Wrong. It's okay to order a pizza, but you should also reach out to the accommodations office to see if they have funding to help.

options.label: Ask the accommodations office if they have funding.
options.feedback: Correct. They may have funding available. And you can still order a pizza!

conversation.question: What am I thinking? I can't afford a lawyer! If I get in trouble, I can just say I didn't know, right?
hints: Ignorance is bliss, some people say. I say be smart and you'll find the way.

options.label: Right!
options.feedback: Wrong. Students are expected to follow their school's policies. In this case, ignorance is not bliss.

options.label: Wrong!
options.feedback: Correct. Students are expected to follow their school's policies. In this case, ignorance is not bliss.

conversation.question: I don't want my profs knowing why I need accommodations. Will the Accommodations office tell them?
hints: Why doesn't matter, only when, how, and what. Your story is yours, to tell or to not.

options.label: Of course!
options.feedback: Wrong. The reason(s) for your accommodations are confidential.

options.label: Heck no.
options.feedback: Correct. The reason(s) for your accommodations are confidential.

conversation.question: So basically I have two choices: fail because I haven't set up accommodations or cheat. Might as well cheat, eh? Worst-case scenario is that I get caught and fail, and since I'm going to fail anyway…
hints: To never have failed is to never have learned. Do what you can and get what you earned.

options.label: It's worth a shot.
options.feedback: Wrong. The consequences for academic misconduct can be much more severe than a failing mark, and your accommodations are your right.

options.label: Noooo, you're better off failing!
options.feedback: Correct. The consequences for academic misconduct can be much more severe than a failing mark, and your accommodations are your right.

boss.question: If you require accommodations, do you have to go to your instructor and let them know what you need and why you need it?

options.label: Yes
options.feedback: Sorry! That is wrong!

options.label: No
options.feedback: That is correct!

conversation.question: OK. Let's go over the assignment. The instructions say Each group member will write an individual research report on a starship manufacturer's marketing strategy. Then, for the final project, your group will work as a team to create a synthesized report detailing the similarities and differences between the companies' strategies and suggesting best practices for future starship marketing.
Dibs on the Centauri Astrodrive! Have you seen their new sport model?
It's so sweet! As soon as I'm earning the big cryptocoins I'm buying one!
You're dreaming. Focus, team. Let's figure out what we're going to put in our individual reports.

options.label: It's an individual assignment, so we should just focus on buying our dream cars. I like the Alpha Centauri Ferrari - that thing goes from zero to warp 9 in 6.5 seconds!
Each marketing report should include the company's mission statement and goals and a description of several different campaigns. What am I forgetting?

conversation.question: That's my favourite ride too! But if we don't make a plan for what we're putting in our reports, how are we going to synthesize them later? What if we all write about totally different things?
Good point. Okay, mission statement, goals, campaigns. What else?

options.label: Do it! Wait, what did she get on it?!
Let's just figure it out ourselves.

conversation.question: My buddy took this class last year. I can ask her to share her report for ideas.

options.label: Do it! Wait, what did she get on it?!
Let's just figure it out ourselves.

conversation.question: She said she got an "A," but who knows for sure?
Can't hurt to have a look at it, right?

options.label: Right, no harm no foul!
I don't know. My brain is like glue - sometimes stuff just sticks there. I'm liable to copy

conversation.question: Same. Might be a bad idea to look at someone else's assignment.
Pretty sure it's a bad idea to look at someone else's assignment.
OK. So we've got the main categories we're going to include in the report and we're not going to look at anyone else's work. Should we at least create a template that we can all use?
Define "we."
Okay, me. Should I create a template we can all use?

options.label: Heck yes!
Umm, maybe. I'm going to check with the prof.

conversation.question: Will do! But wait, maybe we should check with the prof.
Again with the "we."
Don't think you're just flying along in the passenger seat. You can create a shared document where we can all put our work.
Good call. I'll wait until you check. Meanwhile, somebody create a shared doc for us to put our work in.
Ima wait until y'all put yours in and then figure out how to do this thing...
I dunno I heard if someone uses your work to cheat, you get in trouble too.

options.label: I'm not worried about it as long as I don't cheat. Not my problem if other people do.
Hold on, maybe a shared doc isn't a great idea at this stage.

boss.question: Which of the following questions is appropriate to ask a colleague when working on an individual assignment?

options.label: Which topic did you pick for your paper?
options.feedback: That is correct!

options.label: Can I see what you've written so far?
options.feedback: Sorry! That is wrong!

options.label: Neither.
options.feedback: Sorry! That is wrong! You shouldn't discuss individual assignments at all.

conversation.question: I totally found a source online that blasts the Intergalactic Government's new policy on nuclear waste disposal. It has all the facts and figures I need to write my paper, and the author is just as angry as I am. Jackpot, right?
hints: Soapboxes have no place in academic writing. Avoid any authors whose tone is igniting.

options.label: Ka-ching, Ka-ching!
options.feedback: Incorrect! One indication of a non-academic source is clear bias in the writing.

options.label: Angry and academic don't usually go together.
options.feedback: Correct! One indication of a non-academic source is clear bias in the writing. Other indications are a lack of peer-review, sources that are out of date, and sources written by people who aren't experts in the field.

conversation.question: There are tons of citations, so it must be legit.
hints: From Wikipedia to Einstein, sources can vary. Every weak source is a cause to be wary.

options.label: Fer shur
options.feedback: Incorrect! Not all citations are created equal. Review the sources and make sure the publications are from academic journals or reputable professional organizations.

options.label: Maybe
options.feedback: Correct! Not all citations are created equal. Review the sources and make sure the publications are from academic journals or reputable professional organizations.

conversation.question: Good point. Prof says my sources need to be "academic." Does an article have to come from a library database to be academic?
hints: From garden or field, wisdom can grow, but make sure it's wisdom you've found, not just hot air that blows.

options.label: Always
options.feedback: Incorrect! You have to take the time to evaluate the author, date, content…everything.

options.label: Not necessarily
options.feedback: Correct! You have to take the time to evaluate the author, date, content…everything.

hints: Professional or casual, work deserves credit. Cite where you found it, lest you regret it.

options.label: Yeah, non-academic = common knowledge.
options.feedback: Incorrect! Common knowledge is both widely known and undisputed. Most information is not common knowledge and should be cited.

options.label: That seems wrong. Intellectual property is intellectual property.
options.feedback: Correct. Common knowledge is both widely known and undisputed. Most information is not common knowledge and should be cited.

conversation.question: I can't always find an academic source, so if it's not academic, I just won't cite it.
hints: Professional or casual, work deserves credit. Cite where you found it, lest you regret it.

options.label: Yeah, non-academic = common knowledge.

options.label: That seems wrong. Intellectual property is intellectual property.
options.feedback: Correct. Common knowledge is both widely known and undisputed. Most information is not common knowledge and should be cited.

conversation.question: I'm no expert. How do I evaluate sources?
hints: There's a building of books, but you can find it online. It's chock full of experts who'll help you grow wise.

options.label: Look for websites that are devoted to your topic.
options.feedback: Incorrect! There are a lot of websites devoted to a topic that are not reliable sources.

options.label: Library searches usually let you limit the search to "peer reviewed."
options.feedback: Correct! Peer-reviewed articles have been reviewed by other experts in the author's field.

conversation.question: Hmm. That might not be right. For example, this website says there are 517 varieties of Alluvian tea, and I sure didn't know that. How do I know if it's true?

options.label: If it's on the internet, it must be true.

options.label: Take a minute to evaluate the source.
options.feedback: Correct! You have a responsibility to evaluate any information you include in your academic writing.

options.label: Sure!

options.label: Library searches usually let you limit the search to "peer reviewed."

I'm going to find an assignment from last semester and copy the bibliography. I'll just use the sources someone else worked to find!
hints: To reach a destination, one must commit to exploration.

options.feedback: Correct! While students are encouraged to discuss course content or their approach to an assignment, using or looking at previously submitted student work won't help you write your own thoughts in your own way.

conversation.question: If I have the funds for it, I might ask someone on that site, OutsourcRr.net, to take my lecture notes and write a rough draft. I could have some of my weekend back and would only have to do half the work for that boring assignment!
hints: What tower can stand on foundations of sand?

options.feedback: Correct! Having someone else do work you submit as your own, whether you pay them or not, is contract cheating. This type of academic misconduct is taken very seriously.

conversation.question: Don't get me wrong; I don't mind writing papers, but not when I'm so busy. I don't get what the big deal is if you get a little help. I mean, we're allowed to use a calculator to help with the math in our assignments, right?
